article:
A 'video game console' is an interactive computer that produces a video display
signal which can be used with a display device (a television, monitor, etc.) to
display a video game. The term "video game console" is used to distinguish a
machine designed for people to buy and use primarily for playing video games on
a TV in contrast to arcade machines, handheld game consoles, or home computers.
The video game console was first invented in the 1950s and has continued to
evolve, with the latest consoles being released in 2013.

Video game consoles have used a variety of distribution media, with the earliest
generation employing cartridges and the latest using the Internet and optical
media. Console hardware architecture has also changed greatly with each
successive generation of consoles, making backwards compatibility largely
unavailable in modern-day consoles.

As of 2007, it is estimated that video game consoles represent 75% of the
world's general-purpose computational power. [http://www.sciencemag.org/content/332/6025/60 "The
Worldâs Technological Capacity to Store, Communicate, and Compute Information"],

since June 2000.
